review_blob: 22oz bottle from Windsor Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Mouth-watering aromas of semi-sweet chocolate, toffee, caramel, brown sugar, maple syrup and raisins. Pours a distinctively opaque oily black with a finger of milky black head that dissipates to a thin layer of bubbles in a couple of minutes, with a ribbon of foamy bubbles clinging to the wall of the glass in an attractive silky ripple pattern. Roast coffee and raisins up front followed by a rich chocolatey sweetness with a long pleasantly roasty finish that flirts with bourbon barrel oaky woodiness at the very end. Full-bodied, a little weighty and light on carbonation, possibly due to bottle age. Sweet, mouthcoating and mildly coffee astringent. Another respectable imperial stout from Evil Twin that embraces the roasty character of dark beer without allowing it to overpower the way so many do. Really like to try this one on tap or newly bottled to see if that offers a little more carbonation to manage the weight of the beer a little better. Still not a bad beer by any measure. Skal!

22oz bottle from Windsor Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Red and green apple aromas with a strong impression of cinnamon stick and a hint of caramel apple sweetness. Aromatics present much better above 50 degrees. Pours a rosy tinged lemon yellow with lively soda pop effervescence, no beer-like head. Ripe apple sweetness up front followed by green apple tartness with a nice long crisp and tangy finish. Light, sweet, easy to drink, fizzy and very refreshing. Straightforward, unpretentious and inexpensive "Crisp Apple" American style hard cider made from local fruit by local farmers. How can I have anything bad to say about that? Cant wait to try out the Spiced variant next.

beer_brewer_name: Vermont Hard Cider Company, LLC (C&C; Group)
review_blob: 12oz bottle from Windsor Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Aroma of cider apples mingled with the very distinct smell of red wine, with hints of toasted oak and smoke. Pours the color of strawberry crush with bubbles clinging all over the glass and no trace whatsoever of fizz or head. Taste is not just generically of wine, but very distinctively Cabernet Sauvignon followed up by a super sweet wave of cherries and crisp apple tartness on the finish. The distinctive flavor and mouthfeel of Cabernet tannin is unmistakable. Really heavy bodied for a cider, mouthcoating and astringent just like the wine grape its aged with. Really mixed feelings here. Its certainly unique, but you cant call it light or refreshing. It is extremely fizzy, but dry and extremely astringent. An interesting drinking story to share, but its going to take some time to finish off all six of these.

22oz bottle from Windsor Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Aromas of tangy strawberries and rhubarb, cucumber pickles, salt and a little bit of a funny plasticky or chemical preservative kind of smell. Pours a crisp golden yellow with a slight rosy tinge, exuberantly fizzy with two fingers of bubbly cottony white head that dissipates quickly to a foamy ring, and bubbles all over the glass that just keep rising and rising endlessly like something out of a major domestic beer commercial. I honestly think this is the first time Ive ever witnessed a beer this fizzy in person. All saltwater up front, followed by rather vaguely defined fruity sourness and some maltyness mid-palate, finishing salty and a little starchy with a little bit of the plasticky chemical preservative taste. Not strong or show-stopping though, actually most of the flavor elements, with the exception of the salt, are subdued and delicate, and not nearly as intense as the nose suggests. Just a tangy twist on traditional gose beer for the most part. Light, crisp, refreshing. A little bit seawater astringent, but extremely easy to drink especially on account of the almost surreal endless bubbly carbonation. A very nice gose. Came in expecting more of a fruity character based on several others Ive had recently, but the subtlety of the fruit doesnt really detract from the overall quality. A much more traditional and straightforward take on a gose than Evil Twins other, similarly styled Mission Gose, which I also reviewed about six weeks back. Id do this again, why not? Well done Evil Twin!

1qt mini growler from Urbandale Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Aroma of sweet malted milk and caramel with fainter traces of roast coffee and dark chocolate. Pours oily black with huge bubbly ivory head that dissipates rapidly, which is the #1 thing that clues me into it not being Guinness. Moderate lacing, no effervescence on the glass. Lightly roasty and malty with a mild fruity, maybe even tomato-like sweetness. Very well balanced without any particular flavor element dominating or overpowering the others. Full-bodied and almost as creamy as Guinness, lightly mouthcoating with respectable carbonation making for very easy drinking. A respectable beverage for St. Patricks Day. Not quite as good as Guinness in terms of visual appeal (lacing), creamy mouthfeel or flavor intensity, but still a good beer. Slainte!

1pt 6fl oz bottle from Urbandale Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Aroma is very straightforward and unambiguous gingerbread or ginger snap cookie-like, ginger spice with a definite sweet character and hunts of complementary pie spices like cinnamon, nutmeg and clove, and perhaps a sprig of mint. Pours oily black like a Guinness with a finger of creamy tan head, no effervescence on the glass to speak of. Head is persistent with nice lacing. A lot darker than I was expecting, as the label calls it an Imperial Ale, when it looks and pours very much in the character of a stout. A whiff of ginger up front followed by a nicely balanced combination of medium-roast coffee and bitter chocolate, followed by sweetened ginger and chocolate bitterness accompanied by pleasant malty alcohol warmth on the finish. Full bodied with just enough carbonation to keep it from being oppressively heavy. Strives for creamyness but doesnt quite pull it off due to the strength and persistence of the coffee and chocolate flavors and strength of the alcohol. Mouthcoating and rather sweet, only mindly astringent. A unique and interesting take on a stout. Almost strikes me as an eccentric attempt at a winter warmer or Christmas beer. Brings a lot to the party, but doesnt do any of its parlor tricks terribly well. An experience to be sure, but probably not something Id go out of my way to seek out in the future.

1qt mini growler from Urbandale Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Subdued aroma of cracker bread, caramel, honey and banana. Pours a cloudy, rusty red with a thin bubbly head and effervescence exploding churning and roiling everywhere. Real pop on this one, very much like Coca Cola. Very pretty in the glass. Crisp clean acidity up front followed by dry biscuit and sweet malt with just a hint of ripe banana sweetness and gentle hop bitterness on the finish. Light to medium body, great acidity and effervescence keeping things fresh and light. My least favorite thing in the world might be flat, stale English beer. I was initially put off by the aromatic qualities of this one, probably based on bad experiences in the past with stale Smithwicks and Killians bottles in sketchy watering holes, so it came as a tremendous relief to find the flavor profile so light and fresh and approachable. Probably the best beer of this style Ive had to date, which admittedly isnt saying much. Hats off once again to Confluences talented brewers!

22oz bottle from Urbandale Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Soft aromatics of dry roast coffee, baking chocolate, roasted barley, wet earth and maybe just a little bit of sweet lactose. Pours motor oil black with more than a finger of thick creamy tan head and effervescence all over the glass. Intense roasty flavors right up front tempered quickly by creamy cappuccino creamyness. Bittersweet chocolate showcased mid-palate followed by a lingering bitter roasty finish. Very well balanced. Full bodied, super creamy, rich and mouthcoating with a gently astringent bitterness. Some of the most elaborate and beautiful lacing Ive ever seen in a glass of beer. Another well-crafted stout from Stone. Almost missed my chance to give this one a try, glad I got a chance to in the end. The creamyness of the brew really won me over and reminded me that St. Paddys is right around the corner. Ill be drinking Guinness of course, but Stone Bitter Chocolate would be an admirable substitute.
beer_name: Stone 20th Anniversary Encore Series: Bitter Chocolate Oatmeal Stout

review_blob: 22oz bottle from Urbandale Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Big whiff of ginger right from the get go with a strong suggestion of orange peel, something slightly soapy like cilantro and a trace of cinnamon or nutmeg to round it out. Pours rosy golden orange with inches of massive frothy head, even observing proper pouring technique I only got the glass about half filled before the head threatened to spill over. Magnificent clarity, pretty effervescence bubbling up from the bottom. Unexpected big hop bitterness and citrus up front with a hint of soap, biscuity malt and spices mid-palate with bitterness, ginger and soap on the finish. The glass Im using was thoroughly clean to before drinking. Soapyness is definitely in the beer. Possibly an alkaline fault? Light- to medium-bodied with good effervescence making it easy to drink. Crisp with good acidity, hoppy astringency, but not overwhelming. This was an impulse buy so Im not really sure what I was expecting here. While Im not really a fan of Ginger Beer (proper noun) I guess I was expecting this to be more along those lines than it is. Maybe I picked up a bad bottle or maybe my expectations are way off on this one. Hard for me to judge in this particular case, and doubting I would even like it enough to warrant a second round.
beer_name: Ballast Point Big Eye IPA - Ginger

review_blob: 1pt 6fl oz bottle from Urbandale Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Aromas of English yeast, ripe fruit, lemon zest, cantaloupe and seawater. Pours a faint, slightly cloudy yellow color, more like watery lemonade than beer really, with a thin bubbly head that breaks up into a foamy ring in a few minutes. Salt and crackery malt flavors up front, followed by a tangy twist that strikes me as more pineapple than mango with that gose sourness in play, with a finish of fresh lemons and salt. Complex but inviting and so easy to drink. Extraordinarily light. As light as beer gets and still stays beer. Lightly mouthcoating and sour, balanced by salty gose astringency. A surprisingly refreshing, uncomplicated and satisfying brew. A great introduction to Omnipollo brewing. Would love to do this again and explore the rest of their stable. Cheers!

12oz bottle from Windsor Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Aromas of light roast coffee, salted cured meat, grill smoke, soy sauce and a bit of pear and apricot. Pours a bloody red to oily black color with less than a finger of pristine ivory head that burns off in just a couple of minutes, with very little effervescence on the glass. Flavor is light roast coffee and semisweet chocolate up front followed by salty seawater and light fruit juice. Finish is long and lightly sweet but not cloying. Thin body for a beer of this color and classification. Really has the color and flavor profile I would consider more in line with Irish Red beer. Light carbonation and makes the mouth water generously after each sip. An interesting, unusual, unpretentious and quality brew, as all Big Skys stuff seems to be. The salty, fruity qualities are one of a kind. Im not sure Im head over heels in love with the approach, but its a nice alternative to the roasty and astringent status quo. Having a great time with it. Well done.
beer_name: Big Sky Slow Elk Oatmeal Stout

review_blob: 12oz bottle from Prairie Trail Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Subdued aroma of roasted malt, chocolate chips and baking chocolate with hints of crispy bacon smoke and brown sugar. Pours oily black with half a finger of bubbly light brown head that dissipates rapidly to a foamy ring. Delicate effervescence clinging to the glass. Powerful medium roast coffee flavor up front followed by dark roast coffee, dark chocolate, and wood smoke with a gentle alcoholic burn on the finish. Easy to drink. Has me craving something salty. Full bodied and creamy with good carbonation, astringent like a strong cup of coffee. Very good. An excellent stout with good balance and a little more going on in terms of flavor and aroma than the garden variety stout. Not entirely what I was hoping for from a beer that proudly announces maple bacon chipotle on the front label, but still a very good beer.

12oz bottle from Urbandale Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Straw yellow and extra fizzy, no head. Apple pie up front with a sweet mild berry flavor mid-palate tolerably resembling cherries that fades slowly on the finish with the very faintest hint of bourbon and oak. Light, juicy, acidic and easy to drink with a little something extra you dont get in a standard American cider. No complaints here. Inexpensive, refreshing and great with food. Ill have no problem finishing this 6-pack.
beer_name: Angry Orchard Orchards Edge: The Old Fashioned

review_blob: 11.5oz bottle labeled Aprodite from Prairie Trail Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Wood smoke, molasses, brown sugar, dark chocolate, earth and some lactic aromas with a hint of sour milk. Dense, dark oily liquid with a thin layer of milk chocolate brown head. Opaque coloration, no bubbles touching the glass. Head is creamy and has impressive retention in spite of being so thin. Nice lacing as I work my way down the glass. Dark chocolate and roast coffee followed by dark chocolate and roast coffee followed by that funny souring milk taste and a bit of vanilla on the finish. Long finish really stays with you, roasty and lactose sweet. Still getting that slightly off sour milk aroma. Full bodied and creamy, not heavy on the palate, moderately mouthcoating and not astringent. Easy to drink as any pint of Guinness Ive ever had, funny smell notwithstanding. Not terrible, but I expected a lot more from this. Flavor profile skews heavy towards roasty but hangs on to some semblance of balance of sweetness and creaminess. Vanilla character never really developed for me, and slight lingering sour milk smell that never entirely went away really spoils the experience, no pun intended. Will try this one again one day to find out for sure if this is a representative bottle or spoilage.

275ml bottles (?) in a gift set from Windsor Hy-Vee, 2012 & 2013 vintage, in their own John Courage tulip glass. Both vintages show off well integrated aromas of dark chocolate, buttercream and condensed milk, rum raisins, caramel and butterscotch. 2012 is photogenic perfection with oily dark liquid and more than a finger of creamy tan head with magnificent lacing to the bottom of the glass. 2013 has almost no head at all, but retains better carbonation within the liquid, easing up the outrageous weight of the beer, making 2013 slightly more sippable. Both vintages open with really well integrated coffee and dark chocolate flavors and a pleasant caramel vanilla finish, both with a pleasant belly warming alcohol effect midway from that 10% ABV. 2012 has a bit of a raisiny flavor up front and an excellent buttercream sweetness that really makes my mouth water, but is also a bit undercarbonated and trapped under its own weight in terms of drinkability. Both vintages are heavy, dark, roasty and bitter, not very well suited to extended drinking, not that youd ever find a 6-pack of them for sale. Still a fine beer.

22oz bottle from Windsor Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Sea salt, dill pickles, cider vinegar, pickled ginger, lemon zest and grapefruit soda aroma. Perhaps not what most people would associate with beer, but not unpleasant or offensive. Im game. Pours cloudy blonde to orange, the color or unfiltered apple juice or peach nectar. Very fizzy, big bubbly head like a tall glass of Orange Crush right from the fountain that fizzes away entirely in a minute or so. Effervescence all over the glass, bubbling up from the bottom from start to finish. Huge grapefruit soda acidity up front, making me seriously question what exactly Im drinking here. Lemonade, peach, apricot and crackery biscuit mid-palate with a moderately long salty finish. Well balanced, neither face puckeringly sour nor cotton mouth-inducing salty. Light to medium body, perfectly carbonated, acidic, lively and easy to drink. Mildly atringent in that way gose always are. A truly unusual beverage. As my mind wanders from my drink to other subjects throughout the evening, with its acidity and fizziness and strong citrus flavors, its easy to forget Im drinking beer and perhaps got my hands on some strange mildly alcoholic unsweetened orange soft drink. Still trying to develop a feel for vegetal ingredients in beer, this one is flavored with eucalyptus and while a pickley gingery aroma was definitely perceptible on the nose, I still have trouble teasing any accompanying flavor notes out of the beer. An acquired taste perhaps. Would love to find out what this one is like on a sweltering summer afternoon.

22oz bottle from Windsor Hy-Vee, bottled in Dec 2015, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Aromas of semi-sweet chocolate chips and vanilla, dark baking chocolate, sweetened condensed milk, unrefined cane sugar and caramel. Maybe some non-dairy whipped topping in there too? Very nice. Subtle at first, aroma only improves as beer approaches room temperature. Pours 10W-30 dark amber with less than a finger of head, even pouring hard, that dissipates in a minute or two into delicate lacing. Effervescence on the sides and bottom of the glass also dissipates quickly. Taste is strange, not bad but strange. That whipped topping character really explodes full force onto the tongue right out of the gate, delicate and light and sweet, but not quite pure cane sugar sweet, more like marshmallow cream or nougat or marzipan. Still very sweet, makes the gums tingle. Only the slightest hint of roastyness and then its gone, you have to be looking for it or you miss it. Creamy, medium body, big reduction effect from the vanilla, mouthcoating but with great carbonation to help balance. Certainly one of the sweetest stouts Ive had in recent memory. A bit of an overcompensation for all the stout beers on the market that are overly roasty, I actually find this one a little lacking in that dimension resulting in this super sweet concoction almost more like a malt or milkshake than a beer. A decent beer, the whipped topping/marshmallow flavor is a new and unique, but on balance I think Id prefer something a little less sweet.
beer_name: Avery Vanilla Bean Stout - Bourbon Barrel

review_blob: 12oz bottle from Prairie Trail Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Aromas of roasted malts and medium-roast coffee and coffee grounds masking undertones of vanilla bean and something curious like wet cement. Massive creamy, bubbly head to match or even surpass a perfectly poured pint of Guinness, dissolving quickly into generous lacing. Short-lived effervescence on the glass. Significantly roastier flavor than aroma, dark-roast coffee and dark chocolate up front, roasty malted barley in the middle with lingering chocolate bitterness and vanilla bean on the finish. Full-bodied and creamy, to all outward appearances the carbonation should be more than sufficient, but the mouthfeel still seems heavy and flat for this type of beer. Would benefit from more carbonation or more vanilla. A nice looking beer and fairly textbook example of a roasty stout. Doesnt seem as special or unique as its score here had me expecting, and doesnt benefit from the addition of the vanilla beans as several other brews Ive reviewed lately. At least the price is competitive.

Part 3 of a 3 part Mikkeller Beer Geek vanilla stout review. 330ml bottle from Prairie Trail Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass.

AROMA Rubber cement/skunk smell... uh oh. Lightstruck? Mercaptans? Faint coffee, smoke, bit of citrus acidity.

APPEARANCE Dark cloudy amber, almost soda pop orange liquid with half a finger of fizzy head that burns off in a couple of minutes, effervescence clinging to the sides and bottom of the glass. Tremendous amount of sediment material, I should have poured more carefully. Didnt anticipate that, no live yeast or sediment warning on the label to prepare me.

TASTE Medum roast coffee, coffee grounds, vanilla and isopropyl alcohol. Highly competitive, raw overpowering flavor elements, cant possibly have been the brewers intent.

PALATE Medium to light body, mouthcoating, cloying, overripe fruity alcohol-heavy finish.

OVERALL Cant finish. This ones going down the drain. Cost me $11, pity.

Part 2 of a 3 part Mikkeller Beer Geek vanilla stout review. 330ml bottle from Prairie Trail Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass.

AROMA Muted aromatics, really have to get my nose down in the glass to get a whiff, or maybe its the last beer still lingering on my palate. Coffee beans, cocoa and Hershey bar. More Hershey bar than anything else.

APPEARANCE Pours darker and more coffee-like than Mikkeller Dessert. No head to speak of, only a thin layer of bubbles that dissipates in the distance from the kitchen to the den.

TASTE Flavor is much better than smell. Really well integrated medium roast coffee and chocolate bar with a soft airy vanilla finish that lingers a long time without being offensive.

PALATE Medium to full body lightened by vanilla, slick and mouthcoating with a long finish. Not a creamy or sticky beer.

OVERALL Very good. The aromatics are simpler and more subdued than Mikkeller Dessert and were difficult to tease out on its heels, but Vanilla Shake is really quite a good well-integrated beer with better balance than most stouts, and not as much cavity-causing potential as Mikkeller Dessert. Another excellent vanilla flavored stout.

Part 1 of a 3 part Mikkeller Beer Geek vanilla stout review. 330ml bottle from Prairie Trail Hy-Vee, in a Sam Smith pint glass.

AROMA Hershey syrup, chocolate cake batter, dark baking chocolate and brown sugar masking a hint of banana sweetness underneath. Unexpected. Nice.

APPEARANCE Pours deep brown to black with a finger of frothy, persistent tan head with light lacing. Very well carbonated with bubbles on the sides of the glass.

TASTE Sweetened condensed milk, vanilla ice cream, caramel cream and a long finish of bitter dark chocolate. Very sweet, I guess only to be expected from a beer called Dessert.

PALATE Medium to full body disguised and lightened by vanilla. Excellent carbonation in my experience for a bottled Mikkeller brew. Slick, sticky, chocolate bitter and mouthcoating with a long finish. Not a creamy beer, which isnt necessarily a criticism, just an observation.

OVERALL Very good. Extremely sweet, chocolately and indulgent. One bottle is enough, the beer is excellent but too many would land you in a dentists chair for sure. As my first exposure to Mikkellers Beer Geek series, I feel like Im finally discovering the Mikkeller brewing expertise thats eluded me for years.

For my 10th beer rating on the site, the rating that puts me on the scoreboard for community beer scores, I wanted to do something special and review something I have a personal attachment to and havent had a chance to comment on to date. The brew I ended up settling on is Brash Beers Smoglifter, easily my favorite sweet stout, and probably my favorite stout of the decade overall.

AROMA Dark chocolate, chocolate milk, chocolate milkshake, toffee, cane sugar, caramel, and light roast coffee. Faint traces of plum or raisin hiding underneath. Roasty coffee notes are definitely present but very subdued compared to most heavy stouts and very delicately and exactingly balanced against all the other elements.

APPEARANCE Pours dark from the very first drop, reminding me of the color of Kahlua with an extra dark tan to brown head less than a finger deep, but it hangs on all the way down. Bubbles on the bottom of the glass, not on the sides. Picture perfect.

TASTE Roasty coffee and dark chocolate up front, dark chocolate and milk chocolate in the middle, with a long finish of dark chocolate and caramel sweetness punctuated with a pleasant belly warming alcohol effect. A roller coaster ride from lips to stomach.

PALATE Full bodied but light, lively but not fizzy, creamy, easy, and satisfying to drink.

OVERALL A real treat. One of my favorite beers. Makes me want to curl up in front of a roaring fire with a dense slice of biscotti, chewy icingless brownie, or even a box of chocolate graham crackers, letting it soak up all that malty goodness. This beer is like a tall glass of chocolate milk for a grown-up, and really makes me back to when I was about 10 years old in some strange visceral way. Brash Beer is a young operation that seems to have transitioned majorly in the past 2 years from Massachusetts to Texas, and from wide national distribution to regional taproom focused business. Not sure when or if Ill have the opportunity to try this beer again, but for tonight at least, Im in beer heaven.

AROMA Roasted malt, sweetened condensed milk, milk chocolate, peanut clusters, sugar syrup, creamy caramel and just a whiff of something like maraschino cherry.

APPEARANCE Pours a nice dark amber filling the glass with familiar deep oily dark liquid with a thin head for a stout, hardly a requirement but always an attractive bonus with a dark beer. Light to moderate effervescence with a few bubbles on the sides of the glass and trace lacing around the rim.

TASTE Distinctive light roast coffee flavors up front and mid-palate with a mild sweet milkiness moving in behind reminiscent of cafe au lait. Sweetness comes on quite late and lingers on the finish leaving the mouth and teeth sticky. Carbonation is good keeping the beer nice and light and drinkable. Alcohol is well integrated and not obvious.

PALATE Full bodied, malty, heavy, creamy and mouthwatering. Deceptively light with good effervescence.

OVERALL Another one of those beers that seem like an incredible mismatch of aroma and flavor, but not necessarily in a strong or offensive way Ive found other beers guilty of. Aromatics are amazing, flavor isnt bad, looks and mouthfeel are respectable. Not a bad beer but too bad it doesnt deliver more on taste for upwards of $15/bottle.

AROMA Seawater, lemon and orange zest, salty cantaloupe, with a distinctive hint of peach nectar in the mix.

APPEARANCE Beautiful golden straw yellow pour with good clarity, highly effervescent with bubbles clinging to the sides of the glass, frothy white bubbly head reminiscent of seafoam burning away to nice delicate lacing.

TASTE Really salty. Salty and sour. Saltier than any gose Ive ever had to date. Flavor profile doesnt quite live up to the aroma, mostly salty and sour candy sour without much of the anticipated citrus flavors. Theres supposed to be herbs, moss and seaweed in the beer too, but I cant say I detect anything like that.

PALATE Light bodied, fizzy, astringent in an unusual way due to the high level of saltiness, makes the mouth water a great deal on the finish with all the salt and sour.

OVERALL Alright, not terrible. Better paired with something rich or sweet to take the edge of the extreme saltiness. Not well suited to extended drinking on its own. Several other excellent goses in circulation right now with more balance to them that make better choices for me.
beer_name: Two Roads / Evil Twin Geyser Gose

review_blob:
AROMA Brown sugar, coffee, sweetened condensed milk, whipping cream, a hint of cinnamon and nutmeg. No alcohol smell to speak of, in contrast to several other heavyweight stouts Ive sampled recently.

APPEARANCE Big voluptuous caramel colored head frothing up like it wants to overflow the beer glass. Dark oily liquid with perfectly balanced carbonation, keeping it light on the palate without being fizzy.

TASTE Sweet, roasty without the intense coffee notes of many of its peers. Nice balance of malt, sweet, acid, bitterness and creamyness with a well integrated lingering hint of vanilla. Not so much like vanilla ice cream as much as a nilla wafer.

PALATE Light, creamy, smooth, viscous and mouthcoating. Well calculated carbonation lightens up the weight of the beer admirably. Very refreshing as dark stout beers go.

OVERALL Even better than expected. A highly drinkable, exceptionally balanced sweet stout. The vanilla expression is subtle but shifts the flavor profile just slightly in a way that keeps the beer lighter and more refreshing. Seeking this one out again next year.

AROMA Very distintive Guinness-y roastyness, cane sugar, hard candy, caramel and coffee. Faint whiff of peaches or pears.

APPEARANCE Familiar deep Guinnessy-black color with a lot of effervescence clinging to the sides of the glass at first. Very little head to speak of, foaming up upon completion of the pour and dissipating to just a trace within minutes.

TASTE First sip sweet, milky and sugary. Second sip roasty with powerful coffee notes. Cafe au lait? You could convince me this was sold as a coffee stout. Wasnt expecting that. About as sweet as my palate can tolerate. Unbalanced but not offensively so, coffee and milk flavors competing for attention with each successive sip. Short finish, doesnt linger.

PALATE Full bodied, creamy and rich, viscous and mouthcoating.

OVERALL Its alright. Hard as I try I cant seem to get away from the fact that its a whole lot like Guinness, but a good deal sweeter and more coffee flavored. The aromatics are easily my favorite part, nice and complex, but the flavor balance isnt quite right and I dont feel like Im quite getting what was printed on the tin. Next time Ill just have a Guinness.

AROMA Seawater salty gose smell with a hint of lemon and light beer fizz. Sweet ripe fruit juice, something like cantaloupe maybe?

APPEARANCE Pours from the bottle almost clear, and fills the glass like liquified lemon meringue pie, candy yellow with adorable fluffy white head dissolving away to a nice white cover with picture perfect lacing. Vigorously effervescent. Very appealing to the eye.

TASTE Woah! What was that. Second sip. Big explosion of ripe juicy lemons and grapefruits up front, a rich buttery saltyness in the middle, finishing clean with a fresh lemongrass flavor that lasts just long enough to satisfy without overstaying its welcome. Almost like a shandy but no sweetness to speak of, gentle hop bitterness and salt taking the place of that element instead. Very nice.

PALATE Light-to-medium body, slick texture with good effervescence and a moderate salty astringent finish.

OVERALL Not bad at all. Makes it easy to forget that I dont even like light beers that much. Exceptional balance between the salty, fruity, bitter and fizzy elements for a nice easy refreshing drinking experience. These six bottles will be gone in a day.

AROMA Expensive old fashioned sweets. Caramel, vanilla, toffee, butterscotch, chocolate fudge. Smells very sweet.

APPEARANCE Slightly spotty head with a nice caramel color and a thin head that burns away fast and just clings to the glass in a nice silky ribbon.

TASTE Malty, chocolatey, a little roasty with a touch of bitterness. The alcohol burn arrives fashionably late just as the last roasty notes are fading. Great balance among all the different flavor elements. Not actually as sweet as it smells.

PALATE Full bodied, thick and creamy, just enough carbonation to keep it from being heavy or syrupy. Nice long finish with a slow evolution of flavors that invites contemplation.

OVERALL One of the most expensive beers Ive ever bought. Fantastic even at $20/bottle. Lots of flavor complexity that changes and evolves as you work your way through the bottle. A nice long finish. Not as roasty or bitter as the name implies, or as sweet as the smell test suggests. Easy and pleasurable to drink. Pairs as well with beef jerky as it does with champignon brie. Hats off to Surlys brewmasters. Youve got a real winner here.

AROMA Sweet, syrupy, gingery and fizzy.

APPEARANCE Bright, clear liquid pale to amber in color, maybe even a little rosy. Super fizzy like the soda pop it is with a few moments of bubble froth after the pour that dissipates in seconds leaving no foam or head to speak of.

TASTE Light, sweet and refreshing up front like a conventional ginger ale with a good gingery burn in the middle giving over to the burn of alcohol at the end. Im a fan of ginger, which is a definite plus for me overall.

PALATE Featherweight, fizzy and refreshing. Malt beverages dont get easier to drink.

OVERALL Not bad. Sweet, light, gingery and refreshing. Less complex than NYF Root Beer sheerly based on the difference between multi-botanical root beer and single-botanical ginger ale. More of a soft drink experience in spite of the alcohol. Kinda pricey for that, but not much else bad to say about it. Potentially its own hangover cure.
beer_name: Small Town Not Your Fathers Ginger Ale

review_blob:
AROMA Malted milk balls, chocolate milk, candied coconut and fleeting hints of caramel and vanilla. Trying this one for the first time with a cold, not sure Im actually getting the chance to appreciate all the aromatics.

APPEARANCE Indistinguishable from Coca Cola to the eyes. Deep caramel color and unusually effervescent with short-lived bubbly head and a few tiny fingers of lacing.

TASTE Intense, powerful flavor of fresh coconut and coconut candy, intense to the point of overwhelming everything else. The malt, the roast, the fruit and spice characteristics, such as there are, cant stand up to all the coconut and wind up lost and difficult to distinguish in contrast. Truth in advertising to a fault I guess.

PALATE Full-bodied, dark, a little oily, not really creamy in the way you expect from a Guinness for example. Highly effervescent for a dark beer, sweet in the mouth, distinctively green-coconut bitter on the finish.

OVERALL Really strikes my palate as some kind of highly specialized or novelty beer catering to the hardest of hardcore coconut lovers. Not exactly a bad beer on any particular dimension of beer quality, but severely unbalanced and overwhelming in favor of the coconut influence. Not for me.
beer_name: Oskar Blues / Shamrock Death By Coconut

review_blob:
AROMA Bourbon, pitch and ethanol followed by chocolate milk, chocolate syrup and baking chocolate.

APPEARANCE Black coffee with dense chocolate milk head. Just a trace of lacing with very brief head retention.

TASTE Chocolate, unbleached cane sugar, maple syrup, and a hint of buttercream. Unexpectedly sweet with bourbon and alcohol burn on the finish.

PALATE Heavy, malty, rich, well carbonated, coats the mouth and hangs on a good long time after a sip.

OVERALL Very well integrated, complex, sweet, dessert-like, thoroughly drinkable. An unmistakably sweet beer, balanced with malt, roasty coffee bitterness, rich creamyness and lingering bourbon heat. Packs a punch, so much going on and so many contrasting elements to enjoy. A renowned beer worthy of the considerable praise heaped upon it. Great stuff, love to try some of the limited variants some day.
